Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Nanoscience Scholars II program is providing scholarships and academic support to science students pursuing a baccalaureate in any science discipline, with either a minor in nanotechnology or a secondary associate of applied science in nanotechnology degree (in addition to the baccalaureate). The program uses nanoscale science and nanotechnology - exciting fields at the interface between disciplines to attract and engage new students. It builds on an NSF sponsored S-STEM program. This project is accomplishing two important goals. First, it is enabling the institution to thoroughly evaluate whether this strategy that focuses on interdisciplinary nanotechnology, intensive support through the Global Honors Program and the Nano Club science learning community, and increasingly independent research opportunities is an effective and replicable means to encourage more students to pursue education and careers in science and to help them succeed and graduate. Second, by enabling the institution to support additional cohorts of students for four years each, it is creating sufficient critical mass in terms of successful students and graduates over a long enough duration to institutionalize and sustain the program without external funding.

A new emphasis during this phase is on more intensive recruitment, focusing on high school guidance counselors in school districts with a high proportion of underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students. Scholarships are being determined by verified unmet need. Participants also receive a one-time scholarship for a Nanomanufacturing Technology Semester at the ATE Center at Penn State University. The Global Honors Program is helping students succeed through small, dynamic classes, a required first year seminar that introduces students to nanoscience and basic research and presentation skills, and the student directed Nano Club science learning community that helps support, motivate, and engage students throughout their undergraduate career. Optional opportunities to engage in meaningful research with faculty mentors involve students and arm them with the experience and motivation to pursue graduate education.

Intellectual Merit: Nanotechnology is inherently interdisciplinary. It offers opportunities for collaboration across disciplines and is an ideal focal point for attracting students to all sciences. The faculty Nanotechnology Group at the college supports students and models interdisciplinary collaboration. Science curricula require sequential acquisition of knowledge and skills along directed paths. Scholarships help students stay in college and in the sequences critical to success. The program features peer support and research opportunities, and provides the societal and implementation context that math and science courses often lack and are important factors in retaining underrepresented groups.

Broader Impacts: As lead institution in the Pennsylvania Collaborative for Applied Nanotechnology (PACAN), the college is situated to share experience and successes with other universities in the Pennsylvania State System of Higher Education, more than half of which are also developing nanotechnology programs. If nanotechnology and nanoscale sciences prove a logical entry into all sciences, the project plans to encourage other small institutions in Pennsylvania and around the nation to replicate this model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Summary

The LHU Nanoscience Scholars Program has logged a number of successes over its 10 years of existence (AY2008-09 to AY2017-18). This project, the Lock Haven University?s Nanoscience Scholars II program provided scholarships and academic support to new science students (3 cohorts) pursuing a BS in any science discipline, with either a Minor in Nanotechnology or a secondary Associate of Applied Science in Nanotechnology degree (in addition to the BS). The program used nanoscale science and nanotechnology, exciting fields at the interface between disciplines, to attract and engage new students. It built on a previous NSF sponsored S-STEM program (Nanoscience Scholars I) that supported 2 cohorts of nanoscience scholars. Funding helped accomplish two important goals. It enabled us to thoroughly evaluate whether our strategy (focusing on interdisciplinary nanotechnology, intensive support through the Global Honors Program and the Nano Club science learning community, and increasingly independent research opportunities) is an effective and replicable means to encourage more students to pursue education and careers in science and to help them succeed and graduate. And, by enabling us to support a total of 5 cohorts of students for four years each, create sufficient ?critical mass? in terms of successful students and graduates over a long enough duration to institutionalize and sustain the program without external funding.

New emphasis during this phase of the program was on more intensive recruitment, focusing on school districts with a high proportion of underrepresented and economically disadvantaged students. Scholarships were determined by verified unmet need, participants received one-time scholarships to the Nanomanufacturing Technology (NMT) Semester at Penn State University. The LHU Global Honors Program helped students succeed through small, dynamic classes, a required first year seminar introduced students to nanoscience and basic research and presentation skills, and the student-directed Nano Club science learning community helped support, motivate and engage students throughout their undergraduate career. Optional opportunities to engage in meaningful research with faculty mentors helped engage students and arm them with the experience and motivation to pursue graduate education.

Under-represented students groups, especially women and first generation college students, have been successfully recruited and retained in the program [see Table 1]. The nano-scholars have consistently outperformed their matched control STEM majors and STEM majors on a university-wide scale [see Table 2]. Success, in this case, was defined as overall GPA, average number of credits earned per semester, and graduation in four years or less [see Table 3].

We believe efforts are needed to provide additional support services to the LHU STEM students in the courses identified as major stumbling blocks. Such services should include not only tutoring. Matched controls were more likely to change majors after course failures; whereas, the nano-scholars tended to persevere. Therefore, the non-nano-scholars need to be mentored and motivated to struggle through these difficult early courses. As has been seen unsurprisingly all along in this program, students who make it through the freshmen year, have a high probability of successfully completing a STEM degree. 

Changing in funding (to PSU) and the expiration of the NSF scholarship funds necessitated program changes. We brought the entire program to LHU following the building of the East Campus Science Center that included new nano facilities. We developed four new courses and revised to the 4-year tracks in Physics and Chemistry. A proposal is working its way through the local curricular process to revise the Nanotechnology minor to attract non-physical science majors (i.e. Biology and Geology) to take advantage of nano opportunities.

Intellectual Merit

Nanotechnology is inherently interdisciplinary. It offers opportunities for collaboration across disciplines and is an ideal focal point for attracting students to all sciences. Our faculty Nanotechnology Group supported students and modeled interdisciplinary collaboration. Curricula in the sciences are organized sequentially to support acquisition of knowledge and skills along directed paths. The Nano Scholarships helped students stay in college and in the sequences critical to success. The program featured peer support and research opportunities, and provided the societal and implementation context that math and science courses often lack?important factors in retaining underrepresented groups.

Broader Impacts

We shared information on our successes through publications and presentations at national, regional, and local conferences. Students were encouraged and mentored as they participated in the activities of the scientific community (proposing and conducting authentic research projects, presenting their work at national, regional, and local conferences, working with industry partners, and learning to do technical writing).  We have shared our experiences and successes with other universities in Pennsylvania?s State System of Higher Education, more than half of which have also developed nanotechnology programs.

Nanotechnology and nanoscale sciences have proven to be a logical entry into all sciences, and other small institutions in Pennsylvania and around the nation may be interesting in replicating our model.
